clauses.clause: This directive takes effect on January 6, 2025.
This directive replaces the Standard on Security Screening dated October 20, 2014.

Transitional consideration: The Standard on Security Screening Model and Position Analysis requires individuals who occupy positions at the Top Secret or Enhanced Top Secret level to be a Canadian citizen. All individuals in these positions will be deemed to meet this requirement when this directive comes into effect. They will continue to meet this requirement so long as they maintain a valid clearance at that level up to a maximum of five years from the effective date of this directive. This transitional consideration does not apply to individuals who are applying for a new clearance or to individuals whose existing clearance is being upgraded or downgraded at the Top Secret or Enhanced Top Secret levels.

This directive is issued pursuant to the authorities indicated in section 2 of the
Policy on Government Security
.

The Treasury Board has delegated to the President of the Treasury Board the authority to amend and rescind this directive and any supporting instruments, including standards, mandatory procedures and other appendices.
The Treasury Board has delegated to the President of the Treasury Board the authority to issue any supporting instruments, including standards, mandatory procedures and other appendices.

The Treasury Board has delegated to the President of the Treasury Board the authority to grant temporary exceptions, on a case-by-case basis, to this directive and any supporting instruments, including standards, mandatory procedures and other appendices.
The objectives indicated in section 3 of the Policy on Government Security apply to this directive.

In addition to the expected results indicated in section 3 of the Policy on Government Security , the expected result of this directive is to ensure that security screening activities respect the principles of employment equity, diversity and inclusion and that these principles are applied consistently.

header.h3: Senior officials in the departmental security governance
Security functional specialists and other designated individuals

clauses.clause:
Security functional specialists and other designated individuals in the departmental security governance are to:
Coordinate and provide support as appropriate in relation to the departmental security screening control to:
Implement departmental security screening practices as prescribed in the appendices of this directive;
Monitor and report on the effectiveness of security screening practices and share the results with the chief security officer to:
Assess the extent to which departmental security requirements are met; and Identify necessary actions to address any deficiencies; and
Provide advice to the chief security officer and other stakeholders, as appropriate, on departmental security screening matters.

header.h3: Individuals designated by deputy heads of internal enterprise service organizations to oversee their internal enterprise service activities

clauses.clause:
Individuals designated by deputy heads of internal enterprise service organizations authorized to provide enterprise security screening services to departments are to:
Security screening function
Support the deputy head, chief security officer and other stakeholders, as appropriate, on departmental security screening matters, including:
Ensuring that a written agreement is in place for security screening services provided to other organizations pursuant to subsections 6.3 and 6.4;
Make available to the deputy head or chief security officer of a client department upon request and in a timely manner:
Information that pertains to security screening activities and results, unless prohibited by law, including the
Privacy Act
, theÂ
Criminal Records Act
or other applicable legislation; and
Advice and recommendations to support the result of security screening activities and inform decision-making;
Maintain a security file for all individuals for whom security screening is conducted in accordance with theÂ
Privacy Act
and associated Government of Canada policy instruments;
Ensure that personal information for the purpose of security screening is:
Collected, created, used, disclosed, retained and disposed of in accordance with the
Privacy Act
and Government of Canada policy instruments;
Security screening internal enterprise services
Ensure that individuals or organizations that are assigned responsibility for conducting security screening are qualified to do so, including that they:
Perform their responsibilities in accordance with legal and policy requirements, with the security interests of Canada in mind; Monitoring compliance of security screening services against established service standards; and Reporting any issues related to the fulfillment of security screening services to the affected departments and the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat;
Monitoring and reporting
Monitor compliance with this directive:
Assess, investigate and report any significant compliance issues to the deputy head; Take action as directed by the deputy head; and Report findings to the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat, including information to help inform government-wide policy direction and oversight;
Collaborate with senior officials and other stakeholders to respond to direction, advice and information requests issued by the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat.
This section identifies key government organizations in relation to the Policy on Government Security . In and of itself, this section does not confer any authority.

This section identifies lead security agencies or internal enterprise service organizations that have a leadership and support role in relation to this directive and contribute to the achievement of government security policy objectives. The responsibilities of each organization are identified, in accordance with its mandate.

The following roles and responsibilities are supplementary to those defined in the
Policy on Government Security
.

The Canadian Security Intelligence Service is to:
Conduct, on behalf of departments, appraisals of the individualsâ loyalty to Canada and, so far as it relates thereto their loyalty, their reliability.

The Communications Security Establishment is to:
Define criteria and formal control systems for access to signals intelligence (SIGINT) compartmented information to authorize government departments to perform indoctrinations and maintain the national inventory of indoctrinated personnel.

National Defence is to:
Process requests for visits when security-cleared military personnel must visit a government or military establishment in Canada or abroad; and Define criteria and formal control systems for access to Talent-Keyhole (TK) compartmented information to authorize government departments to perform indoctrinations and maintain the national inventory of indoctrinated personnel.

Global Affairs Canada is to:
Conduct security screening of locally engaged staff and of other governmentsâ officials at Canadian missions abroad.

Public Services and Procurement Canada is to:
Conduct security screening of contractors, other individuals and organizational entities as part of the government contracting process, including those participating in foreign contracts; and Manage a visit-clearance request system for visitors accessing classified information in private sector premises and for foreign private sector individuals accessing classified information on government premises.

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police is to:
Conduct criminal record checks and law enforcement records checks to verify whether an individual has been convicted of a criminal offence and, when appropriate, to assess the personâs involvement with criminality or with criminal organizations.

The Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat is to:
Determine the personal information that is to be collected, used, disclosed, retained and disposed of for the purpose of security screening, and maintain the description of the Standard Personal Information Bank PSUÂ 917 (Security Screening) for this purpose.

appendix.title: Appendix A: Standard on Security Screening Model and Position Analysis

clauses.clause: This standard takes effect on January 6, 2025.
This standard provides details on the requirements set out in subsections 4.1.1.1 and 4.6.1 of the Directive on Security Screening .

Standards are as follows:
Grant either a status or a clearance at the level required based on:
The position the individual occupies; or The contract or other arrangement through which the individual is participating.
Security screening model for individuals
Conduct security screening for:
All positions or duties in the Government of Canada; All contracts or other arrangement where there is a need to share or provide access to sensitive information and assets, including IT systems and facilities; and
In accordance with Annex A1 .
Assess:
Reliability, honesty and trustworthiness as a function of eligibility to hold a status; and Reliability, honesty, trustworthiness, loyalty to Canada, and reliability as it relates to that loyalty, as a function of eligibility to hold a clearance.
Position analysis for individuals
Determine the level of screening required for positions based on:
The duties to be performed; The level of authority or control exercised by the position;
The sensitivity of information and assets, including IT systems and facilities to be accessed, including:
The degree of injury that could result from compromise; and The need-to-know or need-to-access principle;
At a minimum, all positions are established at Reliability status when occupied by employees or other individuals working in departments as defined in section 2 and any other agency included in Schedules IV and V of the
Financial Administration Act
unless excluded by specific acts, regulations or orders-in-council; and
In accordance with the criteria identified within Annex A2 .
Top Secret or Enhanced Top Secret level clearances are to be granted only to employees or other individuals who have Canadian citizenship; and
Extend security screening to an enhanced level in accordance the criteria identified within Annex A2 .
Security requirements for contracts and other arrangements
In accordance with Appendix F: Mandatory Procedures for Security in Contracts and Other Arrangements Control of the
Directive on Security Management
, contracts and other arrangements that have an assessed security requirement to a Top Secret or Enhanced Top Secret level are to be granted only to contractors or other individuals who have Canadian citizenship.
Site access screening model for non-employees
Conduct site access screening for:
Individuals who are not employees and have a need to access protected or restricted areas or facilities; and
In accordance with Annex A3 .
Assess:
Reliability, honesty and trustworthiness as a function of eligibility to hold a status; and Reliability, honesty, trustworthiness, loyalty to Canada and reliability, as it relates to that loyalty, as a function of eligibility to hold a clearance.
Position analysis for non-employees
Determine the level of site access screening required for contracts or other arrangements based on:
The sensitivity and nature of departmental programs, services and activities; The nature of the duties or services to be performed; Whether the individual will be escorted or unescorted; Whether the individual requires access to the exterior or interior of a facility; The risk of the individual inadvertently seeing or overhearing sensitive information or conversations; and
In accordance with the criteria identified in Annex A4 .

header.h3: Annex A2: Criteria for Determining Level of Security Screening

ul.li:
Conduct screening of individuals to the level of Reliability:
When positions require:
Unsupervised access to Government of Canada information and assets;
Unescorted access to physical security zones in facilities, where Government of Canada protected information is processed; or
User-level access to IT systems categorized as Protected A or B.
As the minimum screening for all positions.
Access to information, assets, or IT systems categorized as Protected A or B

Conduct screening of individuals to the level of Secret:
Building on screening criteria for a Reliability status and when positions require:
Unsupervised access to Government of Canada information and assets categorized as Secret;
Unescorted access to Physical security zones in government facilities where Secret information is processed; or
User-level access to IT systems categorized as Secret.
Access to information, assets or IT systems categorized as Protected A, B, Confidential and Secret
Access to IT systems categorized as Protected A, B, Confidential and Secret
Enhanced privileges (or administrator access) to IT systems

Conduct screening of individuals to the level of Top Secret:
Building on screening criteria for a Secret clearance and when positions require:
Unsupervised access to Government of Canada information and assets categorized as Top Secret;
Unescorted access to Physical security zones in government facilities, where Top Secret information is processed; or
User-level access to IT systems categorized as Top Secret.
Access to information, assets or IT systems categorized as Protected A, B or C or classified at any level
Restricted access to specific Top Secret networks or systems

Conduct screening of individuals to the level of Enhanced Reliability:
Building on screening criteria for Reliability status and when positions require:
Individuals to perform security and intelligence functions, including:
Uncontrolled access to criminal or law enforcement intelligence information or assets, including IT systems or unescorted access to physical security zones within facilities where this information is processed or stored; or
Duties that support those functions.
Access to information and assets, including IT systems categorized as Protected A, B or C

Conduct screening of individuals to the level of Enhanced Secret:
Building on screening criteria for a Secret clearance and when positions require:
Individuals to perform security and intelligence functions, including:
Uncontrolled access to criminal or law enforcement intelligence information or assets classified as Secret, including IT systems or unescorted access to physical security zones within facilities where this information is processed or stored; or
Duties that support those functions and that:
Require unsupervised access to Secret law enforcement information or assets.
Access to information, IT systems, and assets categorized as Protected A, B, C, Confidential and Secret
Enhanced privileges (or administrator access) to IT systems

Conduct screening of individuals to the level of Enhanced Top Secret:
Building on screening criteria for a Top Secret clearance and when positions require:
Individuals to perform defence, security and intelligence functions, including:
Uncontrolled access to criminal or law enforcement intelligence information or assets categorized as Top Secret, including IT systems; or
Unsupervised access to methods, sources, analytical processes, plans and techniques related to the collection of sensitive intelligence or counter-intelligence information; or
Unescorted access to physical security zones within facilities where criminal or law enforcement intelligence is processed or stored;
Duties that support those functions and that:
Require uncontrolled access to Top Secret assets; or
Unescorted access to physical security zones within facilities where this information is processed or stored.
Access to government information, assets or IT systems categorized as protected or classified at any level

appendix.title: Appendix B: Mandatory Procedures for Management of Personal Information for the Purpose of Security Screening

clauses.clause: These procedures take effect on January 6, 2025.
These procedures provide details on the requirements set out in subsections 4.1.1.1, 4.1.1.4, 4.1.1.5, 4.1.1.6, 4.6.1, 4.6.3 and 4.6.4 of the Directive on Security Screening .

Mandatory procedures are as follows:
Safeguarding of personal information
Assign a security category to personal information, commensurate with the sensitivity of the information, in accordance with Appendix E: Mandatory Procedures for Information Management Security Control of the
Directive on Security Management
; and
Implement measures to protect sensitive information using appropriate security controls.
Collection and creation of personal information: personal information banks
Collect, create, use, disclose, retain and dispose of personal information for the purposes of security screening in accordance with the
Privacy Act
and the
Directive on Privacy Practices
.
Security screening forms and models
Collect personal information using Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat prescribed forms and models.
Consent regarding collection, use and disclosure
In accordance with the
Directive on Privacy Practices
, before information is collected, used or disclosed , obtain informed consent:
Of the individual; or Of the legal parent or guardian when conducting security screening for individuals under the age of 18.
Failure to provide consent or information
When an individual does not provide consent, withdraws consent or does not provide the required information for security screening, cease screening activities and:
When the security screening action is for an initial or upgraded security screening:
Inform the individual that:
Security screening cannot proceed without consent or the required information; and
Failure to provide consent and the required information will result in the individual no longer being considered for appointment, employment, contract, assignment or other arrangement;
Administratively cancel the screening process until consent and the required information are obtained; and Where security screening is being conducted in support of a contract, inform the contracting authority;
When the security screening action is for an update:
Inform and consult with the manager of the individual; Evaluate the risk associated with the individual remaining in their position; and
Where the individual does not provide the required information and the update:
Cannot proceed as a result of the missing information; or
Cannot be completed before the status or clearance exceeds its validity period; and
Presents an unacceptable security risk to the department or the Government of Canada:
Consult with human resources management or inform the contracting authority; and Suspend the status or clearance and initiate a review for cause; or
Where an individual does not provide consent or withdraws consent:
Document refusal of the individual to provide consent and notify them of the consequences of not providing consent; Suspend the status or clearance of the individual; and Revoke the status or clearance of the individual 30 days after suspension if consent has not been obtained within that time.
Security screening file management
Create and maintain a file (record) for each individual who undergoes security screening that contains relevant personal information, including:
Completed original digital or paper copies of security screening forms and questionnaires; Relevant results of all security screening activities, verifications, inquiries and assessments, with each of these dated; Analysis of results and any advice or recommendations to support decision-making; Decisions to grant, grant with conditions, deny, revoke, suspend pending investigation, or administratively cancel a security status or clearance; and Relevant information related to any conditions, temporary access, review for cause, or investigation, and any ensuing decisions.
Update security screening files when:
A change is reported in the personal circumstances of the individual, including at minimum any of the following:
Change in criminal record status;
Involvement with law enforcement;
Association with criminals;
A significant change in financial situation; or
Where an individual works in security or intelligence organizations, additional changes in their personal or legal status;
There is a change in a security status or clearance of the individual;
The security status or clearance of the individual is subject to review for cause; or
A decision is made with respect to the above.
Ensure that any results of department-specific inquiries conducted against departmental data sources and indices are included in the security screening file of an individual only when it is used to resolve doubt. Remove from security screening files and dispose of information related to criminal offences for which the individual received a record suspension.
Transfer of security screening files
Make available the security screening file of the individual to facilitate the temporary or permanent movement of:
An individual within or between departments; or A contractor between contracts;
Transfer the security screening file of an individual:
Upon request and in a timely manner; When they move permanently to another department; In accordance with requirements for reactivation and expiry;
Except for:
Â Any classified CSIS security assessment, which must be returned to CSIS:
Â Advise the chief security officer of the receiving department of the existence of the assessment; and
Â Â
A record of discharge under section 730 of the Criminal Code
must not be:
Transferred to another department, including acknowledgement of the existence of the record; and
Disclosed, including the fact that the discharge occurred, unless prior approval of the Minister of Public Safety is received if:
More than one year has elapsed since the individual was discharged absolutely; or
More than three years have elapsed since the individual was discharged on the conditions prescribed in a probation order.
Upon receipt of a transferred security screening file:
Update security screening activities where:
The results exceed the validity period;
There is evidence to suggest that the security screening was not previously done in accordance with this directive;
There are conditions attached to the status or clearance;
Results of criminal record checks, law enforcement records checks or security assessments have been removed from the file; or
There is adverse information on file that may represent a security risk to the receiving department; and
Record the rationale for not accepting a current status or clearance within a transferred security screening file, and redo the security screening of the individual.
Upon transfer of the security clearance of an individual, notify CSIS via form CSIS 4160 Notification of Change in Security Clearance .
Deactivation and reactivation
Deactivate a valid security status or clearance when:
An employee has:
Retired or otherwise terminated employment; or
Taken an authorized absence from the Government of Canada longer than:
Two years for a status; or
One year for a clearance; or
Taken an unauthorized absence from the Government of Canada longer than 30 days; or
A contractor or other individual has been removed from the contract or other arrangement; or The contract or other arrangement has been completed, cancelled or terminated.
Reactivate the security status or clearance:
Only within the original validity period; and
If an employee returns to active employment and is no more than:
Two years removed from having possessed a valid security status; or
One year removed from having possessed a valid security clearance; or
If a contractor or other individual is no more than:
Two years removed from having possessed a valid security status;
One year removed from having possessed a valid security clearance; or
One year removed from having possessed a valid Site Access status or clearance.
When reactivating a status or a clearance:
Revalidate identity information; Require individuals to account for their activities during the period of absence and the circumstances surrounding their departure; Do not extend the validity period; and
Do not reactivate a security status or clearance and repeat the security screening when:
Â The circumstances surrounding the departure involve:
Review for cause;
Suspension pending an investigation;
An outstanding resolution of doubt; or
Disciplinary reasons; or
Â There is adverse information or conditions on file; or
Â The status or clearance has exceeded its validity period.
Administratively cancel a security status or clearance or Site Access status or clearance once the reactivation period for the individual has elapsed and there has been no activity on the file.
File retention and disposition
Retain security screening files of individuals contained in:
Standard Personal Information Bank PSU 917 (Security Screening) for a minimum of two years following the departure of the individual from the federal public service:
Â Prevent security screening files of individuals who have left the employment of the federal public service from being transferred to the departmental Personnel Records Centre or to any Regional Service Centre of Library and Archives Canada; and
Standard Personal Information Bank PSU 917 (Security Screening) who have been denied or had revoked a security status or clearance for a minimum of 10 years following their departure from the federal public service.

appendix.title: Appendix E: Mandatory Procedures for Resolution of Doubt and Review for Cause

clauses.clause: These procedures take effect on January 6, 2025.
These procedures provide details on the requirements set out in subsections 4.1.1.1.2, 4.1.1.1.3, 4.1.1.2 and 4.1.6 of the Directive on Security Screening .

Mandatory procedures are as follows:
Demonstrate and document that adverse and missing information have been thoroughly addressed; and Conduct a resolution of doubt or review for cause as expeditiously as possible;
Resolution of doubt
Initiate a resolution of doubt when unverifiable, missing or adverse information is uncovered during the security screening of an individual;
Provide the individual with a summary of the adverse, missing and unverifiable information in question:
Prior to disclosure to the individual:
Consult the investigative body when adverse information is uncovered as a result of:
An RCMP law enforcement records check; or
A CSIS security assessment;
Exclude information that cannot be disclosed:
For reasons of national security;
That could endanger the safety of any person; and
That would be exempt under the
Privacy Act
sections 18, 19, 20 and 21, and subsections 22(1) to 22(3);
Conduct additional security screening activities:
To resolve doubt when information is available or reported about an individual that may cast doubt on their reliability or loyalty to Canada; and
Where:
Individual consent has been obtained; and The department has the legal authority to do so;
Before a decision is rendered, conduct a resolution-of-doubt interview to provide the individual an opportunity to discuss any matters of concern and to explain the situation; and Consider information obtained through a resolution of doubt toward the eligibility of an individual to be granted a security status or clearance;
Review for cause
Initiate a review for cause of the security status or clearance previously granted to an individual when:
Information is uncovered or reported about an individual that may call into question their reliability or loyalty to Canada; or
Adverse information reflects:
Recent questionable judgment or dishonesty; or A recurring pattern of questionable judgment or dishonesty;
When conducting a review for cause, in accordance with subsection F.2.2.11 of Appendix F: Mandatory Procedures for Security Screening Decisions and Notifications , pending the outcome, consider a decision to suspend:
A security status or clearance; or Access to sensitive information and assets, including IT systems and facilities;
Undertake the review-for-cause process, as an administrative investigation, including an interview of the individual;
When a review for cause is conducted in parallel to a disciplinary process for an employee:
Administer the processes with distinct decisional authorities; and Record a disciplinary decision in the security file only where it relates to a security concern; and
Consult with:
Departmental human resources management; and
The Centre for Labour and Employment Law, as required; and
Consider information obtained through a review for cause on the continued eligibility of an individual to retain a security status or clearance.
